persona.name: María Elena Sandoval Cruz

occupation.title: Assistant Store Manager / Operations Coordinator
occupation.organization: Mercado Sol (regional grocery/retail chain; family-friendly neighborhood store)
occupation.description: Formally employed with social security benefits, María Elena coordinates daily store operations at a mid-sized neighborhood supermarket. Her responsibilities include staff scheduling for two shifts, training and supervising five shop assistants, handling cash reconciliations and bank deposits, ordering and managing inventory (fresh produce and packaged goods), negotiating with local suppliers (butchers, panadería, produce vendors), ensuring health and safety standards, resolving customer complaints, and doing weekly sales reports for the owner. She often handles promotional signage, organizes small in-store events (Mother's Day discounts, school supply promotions), manages petty cash, and communicates with the central office about payroll and supplies. She is the practical manager on the floor and fills in where the owner needs help: cleaning, paperwork, and mentoring younger staff. Skills used daily: basic Excel, point-of-sale systems, customer relations, inventory rotation (FIFO), and local supplier networking.

persona.education: Completed secundaria and preparatoria in a public school in Zapopan. Later attended Universidad de Guadalajara and earned a Bachelor's in Business Administration (part-time evening program). Took short courses in inventory management, basic accounting, customer service, and a certificate course in small business digital marketing (Facebook/WhatsApp commerce). Informal training from family in textile sales and food preparation since adolescence.
long_term_goals: Secure enough savings to buy a modest single-family home free of major debt within 10 years.
Provide a university education fund for her two children and see at least one finish a professional degree.
Keep the family business stable and possibly open a second small branch or a food stall at the local market.
Retire with dignity and keep strong daily social ties with children and extended family; maintain health.
Pass on traditional recipes, family stories and a sense of identity to the next generation.
Be known locally as dependable and generous — the neighbor who helps during baptisms, quinceañeras and funerals.
Gain enough confidence to someday serve on the local commerce association or cooperative board.
Keep a disciplined emergency fund covering 3-6 months of basic household expenses.
persona.style: Warm, practical and direct. Speaks Mexican Spanish with a Jalisco/central-west accent — occasionally elongates vowels and uses local idioms like "ahorita," "pues," "órale," and diminutives ("cafecito", "niñita"). In public and at work she is polite but no-nonsense, comfortable switching between colloquial expressions with customers and more formal phrasing with suppliers or the owner. Uses gentle humor and maternal tones when addressing younger employees; when stressed she shortens sentences and speaks faster. Likes bright, modest clothing (blouses, practical jeans, comfortable sandals) and carries a medium-sized handbag where she keeps receipts, a small rosary, and a paper notebook. Mannerisms: smooths her hair back when thinking, folds hands when listening, taps a pen lightly while planning, hugs close friends and family, frequently checks her phone for messages and photos of her children. At home she is more informal, sings along to rancheras or boleros while cooking, and watches telenovelas or streaming crime series in the evening. She values punctuality at work but is flexible for family needs; often negotiates with managers and staff using a mixture of firmness and empathy.

traits: Highly family-oriented and deeply loyal to close relatives.
Practical and resourceful; finds workarounds rather than panicking.
Warm and sociable in everyday interactions; enjoys neighborhood gossip but keeps confidences.
Responsible and dependable — she is the person neighbors call in an emergency.
Frugal and disciplined with money, but willing to spend on meaningful family events.
Moderately risk-averse; prefers stable small gains to big speculative bets.
Often nurturing and protective, especially toward her children and younger employees.
Has a dry, self-aware sense of humor; uses jokes to defuse tension.
Occasionally stubborn when her values are challenged (religion, family honor, fairness).
Prone to worry about finances and the health of loved ones, but can compartmentalize to get tasks done.
Community-minded and cooperative — participates in local church and neighborhood events.
Politically pragmatic: values stability and practical solutions more than ideological purity.

openness.description: Moderate. Curious about practical ideas (new recipes, small marketing tactics) but cautious about radical changes or untested trends.

conscientiousness.description: Above average. Organized in finances and work duties, punctual, follows through on promises, keeps lists and a small ledger for household expenses.

extraversion.description: Sociable and comfortable speaking with customers and family; enjoys neighborhood gatherings but values quiet evenings at home.

agreeableness.description: High. Cooperative, helpful, tends to avoid harsh conflict and seeks compromise; forgives easily but remembers slights.

neuroticism.description: Low-to-moderate. Not easily overwhelmed, though persistent worries about money and children's futures cause stress and occasional sleepless nights.

interests: Family gatherings, multi-generational meals and celebrations.
Cooking traditional Jalisco/Pacific coast recipes: birria, carnitas, frijoles refritos, salsas.
Watching telenovelas, variety shows, and streaming series (crime dramas and family comedies).
Listening to rancheras, boleros, and regional Mexican playlists while working.
Attending church on major holidays and participating in parish events.
Gardening small pots of cilantro, epazote and chili peppers on her balcony.
Browsing local markets (tianguis) for fresh produce and good bargains.
Following neighborhood social media groups (Facebook, WhatsApp) for deals and community news.
Helping neighbors with small favors — lending sugar, babysitting briefly, carpooling children.
Collecting recipe cards and handwritten family recipes in a small binder.
media_and_entertainment: Primary TV channels: Azteca and Televisa morning shows and late-evening telenovelas.
Streaming: Uses Netflix and sometimes Claro Video; watches series with family after dinner.
Favorite shows: family melodramas, light detective shows, and cooking segments.
Radio: listens to local AM/FM stations on the way to work for traffic and community updates.
Social media: moderate user — daily on WhatsApp for family, Facebook for neighborhood groups and sale posts.
YouTube: recipe tutorials, quick home repair tips, and sermons from her parish priest.
Podcasts: rarely, but listens occasionally to short wellness or parenting podcasts when ironing or cooking.
food_and_drinks: Loves strong Mexican coffee (café de olla or espresso) in the mornings; prefers it sweetened with piloncillo sometimes.
Favorite breakfast: huevos rancheros or chilaquiles on weekends; weekdays quick tostadas or bolillo with jam.
Enjoys street tacos (al pastor, suadero) for casual outings.
Prefers home-cooked meals; values fresh ingredients and traditional preparation.
Occasional treats: pan dulce and afternoon atole with children on Sundays.
Drinks a cerveza or a margarita on special occasions; rarely drinks to excess.
Dislikes overly expensive or pretentious dining; values portion size and taste.
Snacks: roasted peanuts, plantain chips, and fresh mango when in season.
Seasonal foods: buys mangoes and papayas in summer, enjoys warming pozole in winter holidays.
Allergies: mild dust allergy; no known food allergies.
shopping_and_consumption: Shops weekly at the local supermercado and neighborhood tianguis for produce.
Prefers in-person shopping to inspect quality; buys clothes for children at local mercados and occasional mall visits.
Often waits for sales or pays with debit card; uses occasional small consumer credit for emergencies.
Buys household goods in bulk when there are promotions; participates in informal 'mandados' with neighbors to save on transport.
Keeps a small 'guardarropa' for traditional garments for family ceremonies.
Prefers brands that balance price and perceived quality; loyally returns to vendors who are fair.
Uses WhatsApp groups to coordinate bulk purchases with relatives (e.g., meat for a big family event).
leisure_and_social: Spends Sundays at family meals, often with aunts/uncles/padres present.
Organizes children's birthday parties and half-yearly family gatherings.
Attends local patron saint festivals (fiestas patronales) and volunteers to help with food stalls.
Meets close friends weekly for coffee or a quick comida at a fonda.
Plays simple card games or Lotería with extended family during holidays.
Enjoys short day trips to nearby beaches or local towns for a change of scenery.
travel: Preferred short trips: Puerto Vallarta or small coastal towns for beach weekends with family.
Vacations are planned around school breaks; prefers affordable, family-focused lodging.
Has traveled occasionally to Mexico City for shopping, administrative tasks and family visits.
Careful about travel costs; often uses long weekends and relatives' homes to lower accommodation expenses.
technology_usage: Owns a mid-range smartphone (Android), uses it for calls, WhatsApp, Facebook, photos and mobile banking.
Uses the phone camera constantly to photograph children, grocery receipts and store inventory.
Comfortable with apps for payments and payroll information; uses digital catalogs for supplier orders occasionally.
Not highly into apps beyond social media and banking; learning to use spreadsheets and WhatsApp Business for the store.
Reads news headlines on her phone each morning and saves articles to show family.
fashion_and_personal_style: Preference for comfortable, colorful blouses, practical jeans or skirts and low-heeled sandals.
Owns a couple of nicer dresses for church, weddings, and quinceañeras.
Likes simple jewelry (small gold cross necklace inherited from her mother, a few rings).
Chooses clothing that is easy to wash and durable given daily work and household chores.

beliefs: Government should play a role in guaranteeing basic healthcare for all — supports public clinics and expanded Seguro Popular/IMSS-like coverage.
Corruption is the biggest obstacle to local development; officials often take advantage of power.
Political stability and practical governance matter more than ideology; she prefers parties that promise order and work for local services.
Supports centrist economic policies that help small businesses and protect vulnerable families.
Believes in hard work and incremental improvement rather than risky speculation.
Family duties come before personal ambition in many cases — children’s needs often shape career decisions.
Education is important: wants children to get at least a university degree even if it requires sacrifices.
Faith and Catholic traditions are grounding: baptism, first communions and Mass are social anchors.
Trusts local community leaders and longtime neighborhood vendors more than distant institutions.
Values saving a small portion of each paycheck for emergencies and family events.
Sees small business ownership as honorable and a way to secure autonomy.
Dislikes wasteful spending and ostentation; supports modest celebrations but will invest in rites of passage.
Believes that public safety must be improved; is cautious about certain neighborhoods and advises children accordingly.
Feels proud of Mexican culture and regional cuisine; sees it as identity to pass on.
Supports targeted state intervention (pensions for the elderly, health subsidies) while encouraging private job creation.
Believes in local mutual aid networks (vecinos) as effective complements to state programs.
Trusts medical professionals but is cautious about expensive private treatments; uses public services when possible.
Feels that youth should get vocational options as well as university routes — trades are valid livelihoods.
Prefers incremental reforms that improve daily life (better trash collection, street lighting) over grand ideological projects.
Believes that politicians should be held accountable and that voting matters even if outcomes are imperfect.
Has mixed feelings about migration to the U.S.: understands the economic logic but worries about social costs and family separation.
Sees women's roles as flexible: women can be breadwinners but should be able to choose family-friendly work schedules.
Believes in personal responsibility for household finances but supports government help in crises (floods, health emergencies).
Respects older generations' authority but believes young people should have a voice in family decisions.
Feels that good neighbors and reputation in the barrio are important assets.
Believes cultural Catholic rituals are valuable even for moderately observant families; finds comfort in religious festivals.
Supports local business cooperatives and small-scale public works that create immediate jobs.
Is skeptical about big privatizations that prioritize profit over community access to services.
Believes that police and public institutions should be reformed to be more professional and less corrupt.
Supports vaccination and public health campaigns when information is clear and accessible.
Believes in the dignity of manual and service work; sees no shame in jobs considered 'low status' if they provide for the family.
Feels that democracy needs better local participation and honest mayors who deliver basic services.
skills: Staff supervision and informal HR: hiring, training, scheduling, and conflict mediation.
Inventory management: ordering, rotation, loss prevention and supplier negotiation.
Basic bookkeeping and cash reconciliation; manages petty cash and prepares weekly sales summaries.
Point-of-sale systems and basic Excel spreadsheets for tracking promotions and stock.
Customer service and upselling combined with patience to de-escalate complaints.
Event and promotion organization for the store (discount days, holiday displays).
Cooking and food preparation — able to prepare large family meals and small catering for events.
Household budgeting and informal saving strategies; experience with basic savings accounts and layaway plans.
Proficient Spanish literacy and practical written communication for receipts and supplier notes.
Conversational English (basic phrases for work and travel) and practical ability to use translation apps.
Social media for commerce: maintains a Facebook list of available seasonal items and WhatsApp lists for repeat customers.
Sewing basics and garment repair learned from family, useful for personal and small mending tasks.
First aid and basic childcare skills; comfortable handling minor injuries and common childhood illnesses.
Driving a compact car for grocery runs and small deliveries.
Negotiation skills with local vendors to get favorable terms when buying in bulk.

general: Keeps a small paper ledger at home for daily household expenses and a separate notebook for store orders.
Checks WhatsApp messages first thing in the morning for family updates and supplier confirmations.
Greets most customers by name and remembers recurring preferences ("la señora que compra plátanos maduros").
Brings homemade food to work occasionally and shares with staff as a morale gesture.
Is punctual to opening shifts but will step out briefly for school-related emergencies.
Prefers to negotiate in person; distrusts long phone-only interactions for important deals.
When stressed, cleans a visible surface (kitchen counter, store shelf) to regain a sense of control.
Prays briefly before important family decisions and during celebrations gives thanks publicly.

morning: Wakes around 5:30–6:00 AM on workdays; prays a short rosary or reflection while preparing breakfast.
Prepares a thermos of coffee and a light breakfast for herself and children; helps the youngest get ready.
Checks store inventory list and supplier messages while getting dressed; leaves by 7:15 AM.
Drives or takes short colectivo ride to the store; reviews daily sales target with staff before opening.
workday: Opens the store, inspects produce and ready-to-eat items, adjusts prices and displays as needed.
Spends mornings on vendor deliveries and cash handling; afternoons on paperwork and small administrative tasks.
Takes a 30-45 minute lunch, often at a nearby fonda with a trusted employee or on-site while supervising.
Closes accounts with the cashier at the end of the day, logs discrepancies, and prepares deposits.
Schedules brief calls with family in the evening to coordinate school, chores and upcoming events.
evening: Arrives home between 7:00–8:30 PM depending on overtime; prepares dinner and helps children with homework.
Watches television with family — telenovela or a streaming series; sometimes joins a WhatsApp group chat with extended family.
Reviews next day’s orders and writes a short to-do list before bed.
Usually in bed by 11:00 PM, but sometimes later after finishing household chores.
weekend: Sundays often reserved for an extended family lunch; participates in parish Mass on important holidays.
Visits mother or in-laws, attends local market and arranges household maintenance tasks.
Meantimes, does laundry, irons school uniforms, and prepares larger batches of food for the week.
Has occasional evenings out with friends for coffee or a casual meal; sometimes visits the cinema for mainstream films.

medical_history: Had two pregnancies: one vaginal delivery and one C-section (younger child) without major complications.
Mild, intermittent lower back pain related to long hours standing at the store; uses over-the-counter analgesics and occasional physiotherapy.
Mild seasonal allergies (dust and pollen); keeps antihistamines at home.
Dental issues in the past (one extraction, a filling); prefers public dental services unless it's an emergency.
Had COVID-19 in early 2021 with moderate symptoms; recovered fully but remains cautious about crowded indoor spaces.
mental_health: Generally resilient, but experiences episodic stress and anxiety about finances, children's education, and work responsibilities.
Sleeps reasonably well most nights but can have occasional difficulty falling asleep when worried.
Finds comfort in routine, faith practices, family gatherings, and short walks to reduce anxiety.
Has not sought professional mental health services regularly but is open to counseling if recommended and affordable.
health_habits: Non-smoker and drinks alcohol only on special occasions.
Moderate physical activity: daily walking, frequent standing at work, occasional light home exercises and gardening.
Diet: predominantly home-cooked, sometimes high in carbohydrates and salt; tries to include vegetables when possible.
Uses public health services (local clinic) for routine check-ups and relies on employer-provided IMSS or equivalent for maternity and more serious needs.
Keeps basic medicine cabinet: paracetamol, antacids, topical creams, cold medicine, antihistamines, small first-aid kit.
access_and_attitudes: Supports public healthcare and uses it regularly; appreciates preventive services but has occasional frustrations with wait times and bureaucracy.
Keeps basic receipts and medical records in a file at home; tends to prioritize children’s health over her own when budgets are tight.

relationships.name: Javier Sandoval (husband)
relationships.description: Works as a driver for a regional logistics company. Steady, quiet, practical. They have a stable marriage of 18 years; partner in household finances and decision-making though sometimes more reserved about feelings. He helps with maintenance and childcare when his schedule allows. They cooperate on business ideas and family events.

relationships.name: Diego Sandoval
relationships.description: Teenager in secundaria/preparatoria. Athletic, plays soccer in a neighborhood team. Studious but distracted by friends; mother worries about his internet habits. Daughter-sibling dynamic: protective towards sister.

relationships.name: Sofía Sandoval
relationships.description: Affectionate, likes to help in the kitchen and mimic mother's cooking. Attends primaria and participates in dance classes.

relationships.name: Carmen Cruz
relationships.description: Lives nearby; widowed. Very religious and traditional, often helps with childcare and family rituals. Close emotional support and a source of traditional knowledge and recipes.

relationships.name: Rosa Mendoza
relationships.description: Neighbor and confidant since teenage years; they trade favors, share shopping runs and coordinate school pickups.

relationships.name: Lucía Hernández
relationships.description: Works part-time in a school cafeteria; they meet weekly for coffee and discuss family and neighborhood matters.

relationships.name: Younger brother (Arturo)
relationships.description: Works as a plumber and sometimes helps the store with maintenance; financially independent but close.

relationships.name: Store owner (Don Miguel)
relationships.description: Older family friend who employs María Elena; treats her like family and consults her on store decisions. Respects her judgment and occasionally extends credit during lean months.

relationships.name: Neighborhood priest (Padre Luis)
relationships.description: Provides counsel during family and parish events; María Elena volunteers to help at festivals and fundraisers.

relationships.name: Staff at store (5 regular employees)
relationships.description: Mostly younger workers; she mentors them, sometimes acts as surrogate mother figure, negotiates schedules, and tries to keep morale up.

other_facts: Born and raised in a suburban neighborhood in Zapopan; second of four children.
Her father worked in a small manufacturing plant (deceased when she was 19), mother is a homemaker who still lives nearby and helps with childcare.
Married at 24 after a long engagement; wedding was a modest parish celebration with extended family from the region.
Learned to cook from her mother and two aunts; maintains a handwritten family recipe binder with notes in the margins.
Has a modest savings box (alcancía) at home for small cash reserves and a separate savings account linked to her payroll.
Keeps an emergency contact list taped inside the kitchen cupboard with phone numbers of family, a trusted neighbor, and the local clinic.
Keeps a small box with her children's baby items (hospital bracelets, first lock of hair, first shoes) as sentimental keepsakes.
Participated in the local commerce association meeting last year to discuss trash collection and street lighting improvements.
Has a small parking space and owns a ten-year-old compact car that she keeps well-maintained; uses it for family trips and store errands.
Once organized a successful Mother's Day promotion at the store that increased weekend foot traffic by about 15%.
Keeps an inexpensive smartphone plan; regularly backs up family photos to a cheap external drive and to cloud storage when on sale.
Is on a first-name basis with several local suppliers and the small butcher who gives a trusted 'buena ración' for the store.
Has informal lines of credit with a couple of local wholesalers and occasionally with a trusted neighbor who runs a loquera (credit line).
Volunteered at her children's school for field trips and fundraisers; enjoys being part of teacher-parent committees.
Participated in a community thrift swap two years ago and helped coordinate distribution of clothing to lower-income families in the neighborhood.
Has attended one municipal town hall meeting to raise concerns about public street lighting after a minor robbery nearby.
Likes to document family events with a mix of posed photos and candid shots taken on her phone; keeps physical prints in an album.
Has a small collection of religious medals and a rosary inherited from her grandmother that she brings to church on special occasions.
Once saved money to pay for a relative's emergency surgery through a combination of personal savings, a local fundraiser and small employer loan.
Stores her receipts and guarantees in a labeled accordion file in the kitchen; this habit helps her when returning items or claiming small reimbursements.
Has a recurring dream of opening a small food stall that sells her aunt's mole and traditional sweets during Saturdays at the tianguis.
Knows how to barter politely and effectively at the market; can read the tone of a negotiation and usually finds a middle ground.
Takes part in seasonal housekeeping rituals before major festivals (deep cleaning, decorating) and organizes relatives to help prepare food.
Remembers childhood festivals vividly: fireworks, the smell of corn tamales, and neighbors sharing food — these memories guide how she celebrates with her children.
Has a mild phobia of hospital needles for herself, though she's stoic when her children need injections or medical care.
Often tapes newspaper clippings or printed articles about recipes, religious reflections or small business tips onto a corkboard in her kitchen.
Has a favorite panadería where the baker gives her a discount on bulk purchases because she brings many customers by word-of-mouth.
Keeps a small private journal where she sometimes writes about dreams for her children's futures and practical plans to achieve them.
Is careful with formal loans; prefers microcredit programs recommended by trusted community organizations rather than high-interest lenders.
Has a tradition of making a special dish for each child's birthday using the same recipe that her mother used, adding small personal variations.
Remembers political family conversations at meals; the family tends to be pragmatic but divided between PRI-leaning older relatives and PAN-leaning in-laws.
Is often asked by neighbors to babysit or collect small parcels because of her reputation for reliability.
Belongs to a small WhatsApp group of mothers from the school where they coordinate schedules, homework and mutual help.
Has a mental list of two trusted doctors (pediatrician and family doctor) who served the family for years; prefers continuity of care.
Once helped a younger employee enroll in a vocational course by co-signing a small advance (repaid on schedule).
Has an ongoing plan to replace the store's aging refrigerator unit by contributing small amounts from monthly bonuses and negotiating a supplier-to-store payment plan.
Enjoys teaching her daughter simple counting and cooking tasks that combine practical math (measuring ingredients) with family storytelling.
Feels a small sense of pride when former employees return to say hello and share news of their own successes.
Keeps a modest list of household repairs to schedule each quarter (plumbing check, paint touch-ups) and usually gets Arturo (brother) to help at reduced cost.
Once saved receipts and photos to successfully file a small consumer complaint about defective appliances bought at a big-box retailer and got a partial refund.
Has a quiet ritual of lighting a candle and saying a short prayer when a family member travels or when there is a prolonged worry about health.
